mn3:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn3:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the bhikkhus,
mn3:2.1: “Bhikkhus, be my heirs of the Dhamma, not of material things.
mn3:2.2: Out of compassion for you, I think,
mn3:2.3: ‘How can my disciples become heirs of the Dhamma, not of material things?’
mn3:2.4: If you become heirs of material things, not of the Dhamma, that will make you liable to reproach:
mn3:2.5: ‘The Teacher’s disciples live as heirs of material things, not of the Dhamma.’
mn3:2.6: And it will make me liable to reproach:
mn3:2.7: ‘The Teacher’s disciples live as heirs of material things, not of the Dhamma.’
mn3:2.8: If you become heirs of the Dhamma, not of material things, that will make you not liable to reproach:
mn3:2.9: ‘The Teacher’s disciples live as heirs of the Dhamma, not of material things.’
mn3:2.10: And it will make me not liable to reproach:
mn3:2.11: ‘The Teacher’s disciples live as heirs of the Dhamma, not of material things.’
mn3:2.12: So, bhikkhus, be my heirs of the Dhamma, not of material things.
mn3:2.13: Out of compassion for you, I think,
mn3:2.14: ‘How can my disciples become heirs of the Dhamma, not of material things?’
mn3:3.1: Suppose that I had eaten and refused more food, being full, and having had as much as I needed.
mn3:3.2: And there was some extra almsfood that was going to be thrown away.
mn3:3.3: Then two bhikkhus were to come who were weak with hunger.
mn3:3.5: ‘Bhikkhus, I have eaten and refused more food, being full, and having had as much as I need.
mn3:3.6: And there is this extra almsfood that’s going to be thrown away.
mn3:3.7: Eat it if you like. Otherwise I’ll throw it out where there is little that grows, or drop it into water that has no living creatures.’
mn3:3.8: Then one of those bhikkhus would think,
mn3:3.9: ‘The Buddha has eaten and refused more food.
mn3:3.10: And he has some extra almsfood that’s going to be thrown away.
mn3:3.11: If we don’t eat it he’ll throw it away.
mn3:3.12: But the Buddha has also said:
mn3:3.13: “Be my heirs of the Dhamma, not of material things.”
mn3:3.14: And almsfood is one of the material things.
mn3:3.15: Instead of eating this almsfood, why don’t I spend this day and night weak with hunger?’
mn3:3.16: And that’s what he would do.
mn3:3.17: Then the second of those bhikkhus would think,
mn3:3.18: ‘The Buddha has eaten and refused more food.
mn3:3.19: And he has some extra almsfood that’s going to be thrown away.
mn3:3.20: If we don’t eat it he’ll throw it away.
mn3:3.21: Why don’t I eat this almsfood, then spend the day and night having got rid of my hunger and weakness?’
mn3:3.22: And that’s what he would do.
mn3:3.23: Even though that bhikkhu, after eating the almsfood, would spend the day and night rid of hunger and weakness, it is the former bhikkhu who is more worthy of respect and praise.
mn3:3.25: Because for a long time, that will lead to that bhikkhu’s fewness of wishes, contentment, wearing away [of defilements], unburdensomeness, and arousal of effort.
mn3:3.26: So, bhikkhus, be my heirs of the Dhamma, not of material things.
mn3:3.27: Out of compassion for you, I think,
mn3:3.28: ‘How can my disciples become heirs of the Dhamma, not of material things?’”
mn3:4.1: That is what the Buddha said.
mn3:4.2: When he had spoken, the Excellent One got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.
mn3:4.3: Then soon after the Buddha left, Venerable Sāriputta said to the bhikkhus,
mn3:5.1: “Friends, how do the disciples of a Teacher who lives in seclusion not train in seclusion? And how do they train in seclusion?”
mn3:5.2: “Friend, we would travel a long way to learn the meaning of this statement in the presence of Venerable Sāriputta.
mn3:5.3: May Venerable Sāriputta himself please clarify the meaning of this.
mn3:5.4: The bhikkhus will listen and remember it.”
mn3:5.5: ”Well then, friends, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
mn3:6.1: “Friends, how do the disciples of a Teacher who lives in seclusion not train in seclusion?
mn3:6.2: The disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion do not train in seclusion.
mn3:6.3: They don’t give up what the Teacher tells them to give up.
mn3:6.4: They’re indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion.
mn3:6.5: In this case, the senior bhikkhus should be criticized on three grounds.
mn3:6.6: ‘The disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion do not train in seclusion.’
mn3:6.8: ‘They don’t give up what the Teacher tells them to give up.’
mn3:6.10: ‘They’re indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion.’
mn3:6.12: The senior bhikkhus should be criticized on these three grounds.
mn3:6.13: In this case, the middle bhikkhus
mn3:6.14: and the junior bhikkhus should be criticized on the same three grounds.
mn3:6.22: This is how the disciples of a Teacher who lives in seclusion do not train in seclusion.
mn3:7.1: And how do the disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion train in seclusion?
mn3:7.2: The disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion train in seclusion.
mn3:7.3: They give up what the Teacher tells them to give up.
mn3:7.4: They’re not indulgent or slack; they neglect backsliding and are leaders in seclusion.
mn3:7.5: In this case, the senior bhikkhus should be praised on three grounds.
mn3:7.6: ‘The disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion train in seclusion.’
mn3:7.8: ‘They give up what the Teacher tells them to give up.’
mn3:7.10: ‘They’re not indulgent or slack; they neglect backsliding and are leaders in seclusion.’
mn3:7.12: The senior bhikkhus should be praised on these three grounds.
mn3:7.13: In this case, the middle bhikkhus
mn3:7.14: and the junior bhikkhus should be praised on the same three grounds.
mn3:7.22: This is how the disciples of a Teacher who lives in seclusion train in seclusion.
mn3:8.1: Friends, what is harmful is greed and aversion.
mn3:8.2: There is a middle way of practice for giving up greed and aversion. It gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and Nibbāna.
mn3:8.3: And what is that middle way of practice?
mn3:8.4: It is simply this Noble Eightfold Path, that is:
mn3:8.5: right view, right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right recollection, and right composure.
mn3:8.6: This is that middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and Nibbāna.
mn3:9-15.1: Friends, what is harmful is anger and resentment. …
mn3:9-15.8: There is a middle way of practice for giving up indulgence and carelessness. It gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and Nibbāna.
mn3:9-15.9: And what is that middle way of practice?
mn3:9-15.10: It is simply this Noble Eightfold Path, that is:
mn3:9-15.11: right view, right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right recollection, and right composure.
mn3:9-15.12: This is that middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and Nibbāna.”
mn3:9-15.13: This is what Venerable Sāriputta said.
mn3:9-15.14: Pleased, the bhikkhus delighted in what Venerable Sāriputta said.
